Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Antarctic Ecosystems across the Permian-Triassic Boundary: Integrating Paleobotany, Sedimentology, and Paleoecology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The focus of this proposal is to collect fossil plants and palynomorphs from Permian-Triassic (P-T) rocks of the central Transantarctic Mountains (CTM), together with detailed data on sedimentologic and paleoecologic depositional environments. Fossil plants are important climate proxies that offer a unique window into the past, and the CTM fossils are an important source of data on the ways that plants responded to a strongly seasonal, polar light regime during a time of global change. The proposed project uses paleobotanical expertise, integrated with detailed sedimentology and stratigraphy, to reconstruct Permian-Triassic plant communities and their paleoenvironments. This interdisciplinary approach could uncover details of Antarctica?s complex late Paleozoic and Mesozoic environmental and climatic history which included: 1) deglaciation, 2) development and evolution of a post-glacial landscape and biota, 3) environmental and biotic change associated with the end-Permian mass extinction, 4) environmental recovery in the earliest Triassic, 5) strong, possible runaway Triassic greenhouse, and 6) widespread orogenesis and development of a foreland basin system. The PIs will collect compression floras both quantitatively and qualitatively to obtain biodiversity and abundance data. Since silicified wood is also present, the PIs will analyze tree rings and growth in a warm, high-latitude environment for which there is no modern analogue. Fossil plants from the CTM can provide biological and environmental information to: 1) interpret paleoclimate when Gondwana moved from icehouse to greenhouse conditions; 2) trace floral evolution across the P-T boundary; 3) reconstruct Antarctic plant life; 4) further understanding of plant adaptations to high latitudes. The Intellectual Merit of the research includes: 1) tracing floral evolution after the retreat of glaciers; 2) examining floral composition and diversity across the PTB; and 3) obtaining data on the recovery of these ecosystems in the Early Triassic, as well as changes in floral cover and diversity in the Early-Middle Triassic. Antarctica is the only place on Earth that includes extensive outcrops of terrestrial rocks, combined with widespread and well-preserved plant fossils, which spans this crucial time period.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts include public outreach; teaching, and mentoring of women and underrepresented students; mentoring graduate student, postdoctoral, and new faculty women; development of an inquiry-based workshop on Antarctic paleoclimate with the Division of Education, KU Natural History Museum; continuing support of workshops for middle school girls in science via the Expanding Your Horizons Program, Emporia State University, and the TRIO program, KU; exploring Antarctic geosciences through video/computer links from McMurdo Station and satellite phone conferences from the field with K-12 science classes in Wisconsin and Kansas, and through participation in the NSF Research Experiences for Teachers program at the University of Wisconsin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project was to collect fossil plants and rock samples from Permian-Triassic rocks (260-240 million years old) of the central Transantarctic Mountains (CTM), Antarctica. Fossil plants are important climate proxies that offer a unique window into the past, and the fossils from this area of Antarctica are a source of data on the ways that plants responded to a strongly seasonal, polar light regime during a past time of global change. The project included paleobotany, integrated with detailed sedimentology and stratigraphy, in order to reconstruct Permian-Triassic plant communities and their paleoenvironments. This interdisciplinary approach is a powerful tool to uncover details of Antarctica’s complex late Paleozoic and Mesozoic environmental and climatic history which included: 1) deglaciation, 2) development and evolution of a post-glacial landscape and biota, 3) environmental and biotic change associated with the end-Permian mass extinction, 4) environmental recovery in the earliest Triassic, 5) strong, perhaps even a runaway greenhouse in the Triassic, and 6) widespread orogenesis and development of a foreland basin system.

There are extensive, well-exposed outcrops in the CTM where fossils and the rocks containing them record these environmental changes, and where megaplants and palynomorphs are well preserved. We collected compression floras in order to obtain biodiversity and abundance data, and as a data source for paleoecological analysis. Since silicified wood is also present, we will analyze tree rings and growth in a warm, high-latitude environment for which there is no modern analogue. These factors make fossil plants from the CTM an unequaled source of biological and environmental information that can be used to: 1) interpret paleoclimate during an important time in earth history, when Gondwana moved from icehouse to greenhouse conditions; 2) trace floral evolution from the Permian into the Triassic; 3) reconstruct Antarctic plant life; and 4) further our understanding of plant adaptations to high latitudes.

The Intellectual Merit of the research included: 1) tracing floral evolution after the retreat of glaciers; 2) examining floral composition and diversity from the Permian into the Triassic; and 3) obtaining data on the recovery of these ecosystems in the Early Triassic, as well as changes in floral cover and diversity in the Early-Middle Triassic. Antarctica is the only place on Earth that includes extensive outcrops of terrestrial rocks, combined with widespread and well-preserved plant fossils, which spans this crucial time period.

The Broader Impacts components of the project involved education and outreach initiatives that included women and under-represented groups in the excitement of Antarctic earth science: 1) Continuing successful public outreach, teaching, and mentoring of women and under-represented students in Antarctic research; 2) Mentoring graduate student, postdoctoral, and new faculty women in Antarctic paleobotany and geosciences; 3) Continuing support and participation in workshops for middle school girls in science via the Expanding Your Horizons Program, Emporia State University, KS, and the TRIO program, KU; 4) Exploring Antarctic geosciences through video/computer links from McMurdo Station and a blog from the field in the Transantarctic Mountains, and through participation in the NSF Research Experiences for Teachers program at the University of Wisconsin. Outreach and communication were enhanced by publications and presentations to the public and colleagues, and through updates on our web sites.
